Award.AwardTitle: NSF Visitor Support for the NASA Infrared Telescope Facility
Award.AbstractNarration:
The NASA Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF) was established by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration (NASA) as a national astronomical observatory primarily to support spacecraft missions and to obtain infrared observations of Solar System objects. The IRTF is managed, operated and maintained for NASA under a Cooperative Agreement with the University of Hawaii (UH) through its Institute for Astronomy. NASA provides the majority of the operating cost of the facility as well as visitor support for the astronomers carrying out programs focused on Solar System objects. Fifty percent of the available observing time is allocated to Solar System observing programs. The rest of the observing time is allocated to observational programs emphasizing scientific programs outside the Solar System. The IRTF visitor use for these non-Solar System programs has been supported by the NSF in the past. This grant will continue the NSF funding support for visiting astronomers for the IRTF for an additional two years.

From 2012-2016, 539 refereed publications have resulted from IRTF observations, of which 395 are non-Solar System publications. Most of the IRTF staff is based at the UH facilities in Hilo, situated in a largely rural setting with large minority communities. Several underrepresented groups (e.g., native Hawaiian) are employees of UH or are UH students with the IRTF. The IRTF contributes to educational and public outreach within the Hilo community through three major programs: Journey through the Universe, the Imiloa Astronomy Center, and the Maunakea Scholars Program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NASA Infrared Telescope Facility (IRTF) is a 3.2-m diameter atop the summit of Maunakea, Hawaii. IRTF is run under contract for NASA by the University of Hawaii. Fifty percent of the observing time is allocated to solar system objects and NASA space mission support. Under a Memorandum of Understanding between NASA and NSF the remainder of the observing time is allocated to non-solar system programs of interest to NSF. The IRTF Visitor Support grant from NSF funds NSF-related visitor and observing support costs for observers who either come to the observatory or observe remotely. These costs include lodging and food at the Hale Pohaku mid-level facility where visiting observers stay, ground transportation between Hilo and the summit, share of instrument operations (cryogens and closed-cycle coolers) and remote observing infrastructure, and share of a second person (for safety) at the telescope during remote observing. 

 

Dennis Crabtree (NRC Herzberg Astronomy and Astrophysics Research Centre, Canada) produces an independent survey of telescope scientific productivity. In this survey IRTF is currently averaging about 100 peer-reviewed papers per year, of which about 70% are for NSF-related programs. IRTF continues to be highly productive compared to similar sized telescopes (see accompanying figure). The NSF-related scientific results cover a wide range of topics including exoplanet detection and characterization, observations of star and planet forming disks, young stellar objects, fundamental stellar properties, studies of gas, ice and dust in the interstellar medium, novae and supernovae, and active galactic nuclei.

 

In broader outreach, the Visitor Support grant gives graduate students the opportunity to conduct observations at the telescope and see the telescope and instrumentation in use. This is an increasingly rare but important part of student education. The grant also supports observing by Hawaii high school students as part of the Maunakea Scholars Program (MSP). Through the MSP students from local high schools work with IRTF staff to compete for one full night of observing time on IRTF per year. The goal of the program is to inspire local students to pursue careers in STEM fields and to become the next wave of scientists and engineers for Maunakea telescopes.
